subject: Art & Design
title: Visual Hierarchy: Controlling What People See First
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Visual Hierarchy: Controlling What People See First.

hook.text: On a newspaper front page, your eye hits the headline first, then the photo, then the text. That order isn't random.

buildup.text: Visual hierarchy guides the viewer's attention through size, color, contrast, position, and whitespace.

discovery.text: Larger elements draw attention first. High contrast pops. Top-left placement catches Western readers' eyes.

twist.text: Too many 'important' elements = nothing is important. Hierarchy requires sacrifice: some things must be quiet.

climax.text: Apple's product pages master hierarchy: one massive image, one bold headline, minimal text. Focus is absolute.

punchline.text: Hierarchy isn't about making things big.

quiz.question: What happens when a design has too many 'important' elements?
